segment.source: How to-- port a simple OpenGL ES 2.0 renderer to Direct3D 11
segment.target: How to-- port a simple OpenGL ES 2.0 renderer to Direct3D 11

segment.source: For the first porting exercise, we'll start with the basics-- bringing a simple renderer for a spinning, vertex-shaded cube from OpenGL ES 2.0 into Direct3D, such that it matches the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template from Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: For the first porting exercise, we'll start with the basics-- bringing a simple renderer for a spinning, vertex-shaded cube from OpenGL ES 2.0 into Direct3D, such that it matches the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template from Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: How to: port a simple OpenGL ES 2.0 renderer to Direct3D 11
segment.target: How to: port a simple OpenGL ES 2.0 renderer to Direct3D 11

segment.source: For the first porting exercise, we'll start with the basics: bringing a simple renderer for a spinning, vertex-shaded cube from OpenGL ES 2.0 into Direct3D, such that it matches the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template from Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: For the first porting exercise, we'll start with the basics: bringing a simple renderer for a spinning, vertex-shaded cube from OpenGL ES 2.0 into Direct3D, such that it matches the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template from Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: As we walk through this port process, you will learn the following:
segment.target: As we walk through this port process, you will learn the following:

segment.source: How to port a simple set of vertex buffers to Direct3D input buffers
segment.target: How to port a simple set of vertex buffers to Direct3D input buffers

segment.source: How to port uniforms and attributes to constant buffers
segment.target: How to port uniforms and attributes to constant buffers

segment.source: How to configure Direct3D shader objects
segment.target: How to configure Direct3D shader objects

segment.source: How basic HLSL semantics are used in Direct3D shader development
segment.target: How basic HLSL semantics are used in Direct3D shader development

segment.source: How to port very simple GLSL to HLSL
segment.target: How to port very simple GLSL to HLSL

segment.source: This topic starts after you have created a new DirectX 11 project.
segment.target: This topic starts after you have created a new DirectX 11 project.

segment.source: To learn how to create a new DirectX 11 project, read Create a new DirectX 11 project for Universal Windows Platform (UWP).
segment.target: To learn how to create a new DirectX 11 project, read Create a new DirectX 11 project for Universal Windows Platform (UWP).

segment.source: The project created from either of these links has all the code for the Direct3D infrastructure prepared, and you can immediately start into the process of porting your renderer from Open GL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11.
segment.target: The project created from either of these links has all the code for the Direct3D infrastructure prepared, and you can immediately start into the process of porting your renderer from Open GL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11.

segment.source: This topic walks two code paths that perform the same basic graphics task: display a rotating vertex-shaded cube in a window.
segment.target: This topic walks two code paths that perform the same basic graphics task: display a rotating vertex-shaded cube in a window.

segment.source: In both cases, the code covers the following process:
segment.target: In both cases, the code covers the following process:

segment.source: Creating a cube mesh from hardcoded data.
segment.target: Creating a cube mesh from hardcoded data.

segment.source: This mesh is represented as a list of vertices, with each vertex possessing a position, a normal vector, and a color vector.
segment.target: This mesh is represented as a list of vertices, with each vertex possessing a position, a normal vector, and a color vector.

segment.source: This mesh is put into a vertex buffer for the shading pipeline to process.
segment.target: This mesh is put into a vertex buffer for the shading pipeline to process.

segment.source: Creating shader objects to process the cube mesh.
segment.target: Creating shader objects to process the cube mesh.

segment.source: There are two shaders: a vertex shader that processes the vertices for rasterization, and a fragment (pixel) shader that colors the individual pixels of the cube after rasterization.
segment.target: There are two shaders: a vertex shader that processes the vertices for rasterization, and a fragment (pixel) shader that colors the individual pixels of the cube after rasterization.

segment.source: These pixels are written into a render target for display.
segment.target: These pixels are written into a render target for display.

segment.source: Forming the shading language that is used for vertex and pixel processing in the vertex and fragment shaders, respectively.
segment.target: Forming the shading language that is used for vertex and pixel processing in the vertex and fragment shaders, respectively.

segment.source: Displaying the rendered cube on the screen.
segment.target: Displaying the rendered cube on the screen.

segment.source: simple opengl cube
segment.target: simple opengl cube

segment.source: Upon completing this walkthrough, you should be familiar with the following basic differences between Open GL ES 2.0 and Direct3D 11:
segment.target: Upon completing this walkthrough, you should be familiar with the following basic differences between Open GL ES 2.0 and Direct3D 11:

segment.source: The representation of vertex buffers and vertex data.
segment.target: The representation of vertex buffers and vertex data.

segment.source: The process of creating and configuring shaders.
segment.target: The process of creating and configuring shaders.

segment.source: Shading languages, and the inputs and outputs to shader objects.
segment.target: Shading languages, and the inputs and outputs to shader objects.

segment.source: Screen drawing behaviors.
segment.target: Screen drawing behaviors.

segment.source: In this walkthrough, we refer to an simple and generic OpenGL renderer structure, which is defined like this:
segment.target: In this walkthrough, we refer to an simple and generic OpenGL renderer structure, which is defined like this:

segment.source: This structure has one instance and contains all the necessary components for rendering a very simple vertex-shaded mesh.
segment.target: This structure has one instance and contains all the necessary components for rendering a very simple vertex-shaded mesh.

segment.source: Note Any OpenGL ES 2.0 code in this topic is based on the Windows API implementation provided by the Khronos Group, and uses Windows C programming syntax.
segment.target: Note Any OpenGL ES 2.0 code in this topic is based on the Windows API implementation provided by the Khronos Group, and uses Windows C programming syntax.

segment.target: Read this topic to better understand the graphics interface provided by DirectX.

segment.source: Steps
segment.target: Steps

segment.source: Topic
segment.target: Topic

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Port the shader objects
segment.target: Port the shader objects

segment.source: When porting the simple renderer from OpenGL ES 2.0, the first step is to set up the equivalent vertex and fragment shader objects in Direct3D 11, and to make sure that the main program can communicate with the shader objects after they are compiled.
segment.target: When porting the simple renderer from OpenGL ES 2.0, the first step is to set up the equivalent vertex and fragment shader objects in Direct3D 11, and to make sure that the main program can communicate with the shader objects after they are compiled.

segment.source: Port the vertex buffers and data
segment.target: Port the vertex buffers and data

segment.source: In this step, you'll define the vertex buffers that will contain your meshes and the index buffers that allow the shaders to traverse the vertices in a specified order.
segment.target: In this step, you'll define the vertex buffers that will contain your meshes and the index buffers that allow the shaders to traverse the vertices in a specified order.

segment.source: Port the GLSL
segment.target: Port the GLSL

segment.source: Once you've moved over the code that creates and configures your buffers and shader objects, it's time to port the code inside those shaders from OpenGL ES 2.0's GL Shader Language (GLSL) to Direct3D 11's High-level Shader Language (HLSL).
segment.target: Once you've moved over the code that creates and configures your buffers and shader objects, it's time to port the code inside those shaders from OpenGL ES 2.0's GL Shader Language (GLSL) to Direct3D 11's High-level Shader Language (HLSL).

segment.source: Draw to the screen
segment.target: Draw to the screen

segment.source: Finally, we port the code that draws the spinning cube to the screen.
segment.target: Finally, we port the code that draws the spinning cube to the screen.

segment.target: Additional resources
